attributes.title: The Myth of the Misinformed Irregular Migrant? Insights from Nigeria

q1.value: The Myth of the Misinformed Irregular Migrant? Insights from Nigeria

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The last several years have seen vast numbers of migrants, many of them from sub-Saharan Africa, attempt to reach Europe irregularly by way of the "Mediterranean route," a reflection of multiple migration pressures from sub-Saharan Africa that are unlikely to subside anytime soon (Hanson and McIntosh 2016). In turn, European governments have invested heavily in initiatives to deter irregular migration, and there has been an explosion of information campaigns designed to impress upon potential migrants the dangers of journeying across the Sahara and the Mediterranean Sea and the unwelcoming reception they might receive in Europe (Schans and Optekamp 2016). Beyond the urgent political and complex ethical implications of these programs, there is little research on whether they accomplish their stated objectives and there is a surprising lack of evidence concerning the extent to which potential migrants are misinformed about the costs and potential benefits of trying to irregularly migrate to Europe in the first place. We address these questions with a representative survey, including two survey experiments, in Benin City, the epicenter of irregular migration out of Nigeria, which itself is the single largest sub-Saharan African source of irregular migrants to Europe.

q16.value: We will conduct three principal types of analysis with the survey data. First, we will examine migration-relevant knowledge and beliefs and test whether they differ across potential migrants and non-migrants (as indicated by a set of variables related to intent, willingness, and planning). We will also provide descriptive summaries of each of these sets of items as well as family and household-level migration histories, and we will assess the spatial distributions of these indicators across Benin City. Second, we will test a set of hypotheses concerning correlates of both migration-related knowledge and beliefs as well as migration intent (including gender, socioeconomic measures, household shocks, cognitive ability, attitudes toward risk and time discounting, exposure to violence and insecurity, political satisfaction, social networks and social media engagement). Third, we estimate the effects of subjects being assigned to control or treatment conditions in two survey experiments, in which subjects are provided with (a) either a placebo statement or information from the German government about life in Germany, and (b) either a placebo statement or information from the International Organization for Migration (IOM) about the risks of the irregular migration journey. Our core outcome of interest is subjects’ interest in migrating irregularly. We allow treatment effects to vary by prior knowledge, gender, and socioeconomic measures. See the detailed pre-analysis plan for further information.

q17.value: For each comparison, we will report regression results and classic hypothesis tests. When appropriate, we adjust for potentially remaining imbalances in our data by including a relevant set of control variables. We will report difference-in-differences estimates when possible. See the detailed pre-analysis plan for further information.

q19.value: The target sample size is 500 randomly sampled households. A short-form interview is conducted with the head/senior member of each household and an in-depth interview with a randomly sampled household member.

attributes.title: Understanding Attitudes toward Syrian Refugees in Jordan

q1.value: Understanding Attitudes toward Syrian Refugees in Jordan

q2.value: Ala' Alrababa'h | Andrea Dillon | Scott Williamson | Jens Hainmueller | Dominik Hangartner | Duncan Lawrence | Jeremy Weinstein

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The project explores attitudes toward Syrian refugees in Jordan as well as strategies for mitigating tensions between the refugee and host communities. Jordan currently hosts over 1 million Syrians, and though the country has a long history of welcoming refugees, the scale of the influx has strained resources and contributed to tensions. The study uses an online survey, with Jordanian respondents recruited through Facebook. It includes two experimental components: an attitudinal survey experiment and a conjoint experiment. The attitudinal experiment will test several treatments that are designed to leverage insights from the literature on charitable giving. The conjoint experiment will evaluate the drivers of Jordanian attitudes toward Syrian refugees.

q16.value: The attitudinal experiments will evaluate whether exposure to information and videos meant to induce mechanisms for increasing generosity can improve Jordanian attitudes toward Syrian refugees. The study includes five such treatments, which are randomly assigned with equal probability. The mechanisms are: raising awareness of refugee need; raising awareness of the benefits associated with Jordan's assistance for refugees; creating a warm glow from giving; and priming religious values. The awareness of need mechanism includes two treatments. We will test for interactions with Palestinian-Jordanian identity, education, age, gender, income, and frequency of contact with Syrians. The conjoint analysis will evaluate the effects of 11 attributes: gender; age; occupation in Jordan; receiving benefits from UNHCR; place of residence in Jordan; education level; religious sect; religiosity; place of residence in Syria; reason for fleeing Syria; and family status. We will look for sub-group effects among educated and higher-income respondents, urban and rural respondents, respondents with children, and Palestinian-Jordanians. We will also explore interactions between the attributes. See the pre-analysis plan for more details.

q17.value: The attitudinal experiments will be analyzed with OLS regressions using robust standard errors. We will test effects on several outcome questions and on an index of the outcome questions designed using polychoric PCA. The analysis will be conducted with no covariates; with a set of limited covariates; and a more extended set of covariates. The conjoint analysis will be analyzed using standard methods, with the AMCE estimated by regressing the outcomes on dummy variables for each of the attribute levels. Standard errors will be clustered by respondent. For both sets of analysis, we will report both weighted and unweighted results, with weights taken from Jordan's 2015 census.

attributes.title: Framing Financial Rescues as Migration Prevention

q1.value: Framing Financial Rescues as Migration Prevention

q2.value: David Leblang | Christina J. Schneider | Jennifer L. Tobin

q5.value: We thank Michael Bechtel, Ken Scheve, Dan Nielson, Ryan Brutger and Dustin Tingley for valuable input on the design of the survey experiment.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This study aims to analyze whether voters’ attitudes toward U.S. foreign economic policies (especially, bilateral bailouts) are affected by how politicians frame these issues. We are particularly interested in analyzing whether voters (a) increase their support for a bailout if that bailout is framed as a migration-prevention tool or as a tool to protect American jobs and (b) decrease their support for a bailout if that bailout is framed as a tool to protect exposed American banks. We are also interested in analyzing whether stronger anti-bailout mechanisms affect these relationships. The registered survey experiment is part of a larger research project on the ability of governments to pursue unpopular foreign economic policies (especially, bailouts) where we argue that governments are more likely to provide bailouts when they can credibly frame it as migration prevention.

q16.value: 1) Voters should increase their support for a loan/politician under the immigration treatment (T3) as compared to the control group. 2) Voters should increase their support for a loan/politician under the jobs treatment (T2) as compared to the control group. 3) Voters should decrease their support for a loan/politician under the banks treatment (T1) as compared to the control group and as compared to the jobs/immigration treatment. 4) The expected effects in 1)-3) should be dampened by the negative treatment (T 2-1) as relative to the second control group. 5) The positive effect of 1) should be greater for respondents who are more concerned about migration. 6) The effects expected in 1)-4) should be dampened for respondents with more nationalistic or egocentric views 7) The effects expected in 1)-5) should not depend on partisanship affiliation of the respondents.

q17.value: Many Latin American countries are currently experiencing economic and financial turmoil. Some U.S. politicians believe that if one of these countries were to experience a financial crisis, it should receive a loan from the U.S. government [Control: "."; Treatment 1-1: "to protect exposed American banks from the risk of default."; Treatment 1-2: "to protect American jobs in industries that export to those countries."; Treatment 1-3: "to protect against an influx of immigration from those countries to the U.S."] Other U.S. politicians believe that the U.S. government should not provide a loan in this situation [Control: “."; Treatment 2-1: "because the U.S. should not bail out countries for their own mistakes.” See pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The survey examines American voters’ preferences for government spending on national defense.

q16.value: The survey is designed to test the hypothesis that the benefit leaders receive from appearing competent on national security issues outweighs the cost leaders suffer from promising to raise defense spending.

q17.value: The survey contains a simple conjoint experiment. The full survey instrument is enclosed along with a pre-analysis plan.

attributes.title: Elite Perceptions and Violent Electoral Tactics: A Information Experiment in Kenya

q1.value: Elite Perceptions and Violent Electoral Tactics: A Information Experiment in Kenya

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The purpose of the study is to investigate whether providing Kenyan politicians with information about the negative effects of violent campaign tactics on voter support (information generated by a previous study of voter behavior) affects the campaign tactics they use in their election campaigns. Previous research by the PI has found that politicians underestimate the electoral costs of violent campaign tactics, so the study seeks to determine whether providing systematic information about the efficacy of these tactics changes their campaign behavior, in particular whether providing such information reduces the use of violence and heated ethnic rhetoric.

q16.value: The study will test whether providing information about how violence and ethnic rhetoric costs politicians voter support affects the incidence of these electoral strategies. It will also test whether making this information common knowledge among candidates competing against one another moderate the treatment effect. Hypothesis 1 is that providing information about the electoral costs of violence and ethnic rhetoric to candidates for MP in a parliamentary constituency will reduce the incidence violence and ethnic appeals in that constituency. Hypotheses 2 and 3 conflict, reflecting some theoretical uncertainty about the effects of common knowledge. Hypothesis 2 is that informing candidates that other candidates in the constituency are receiving the same information about the electoral costs of violence and ethnic rhetoric will increase the negative effect of the information on violence and ethnic rhetoric by lowering the risk of running nonviolent, non-ethnic campaigns. Hypothesis 3 is that informing candidates that other candidates in the constituency are receiving the same information about the electoral costs of violence and ethnic rhetoric will decrease the negative effect of the information on violence and ethnic rhetoric because candidates will not believe the information, and they will see the potential payoff from using such tactics as greater since other candidates may believe the information and refrain from using them.

q17.value: The study intervention involves sending a 3-page memo--with a short cover note--summarizing the results of previous research suggesting that violence and ethnic rhetoric costs Kenyan politicians votes when running for elected office. The cover note and memo also include links to a working paper and dissertation that describes the previous research and its results in much greater detail. The information is being sent to all candidates in treated parliamentary constituencies for whom the researcher was able to find any contact information. The four modes of contact include 1) email, 2) SMS, 3) Facebook message, and 4) Twitter message. Candidates will be contacted using all modes available to the researcher. In one treatment arm, candidates simply receive the information. In a second treatment arm, they receive the same information but are also explicitly informed that other candidates in the constituency are receiving the same information. Treatment assignment of Kenya's 290 parliamentary constituencies is block randomized, blocking on the country's eight (no longer official) regions and whether the constituency vote in the previous 2013 election was above or below the median for the incumbent president. Half (145) of the constituencies are assigned to one of the two treatment arms, with half of those treated assigned to the information only treatment, and half to the information plus common knowledge treatment. The treatment will first be administered 8 weeks prior to the election date, and repeated every two weeks until two weeks before the election (for a total of 4 separate contact points). If the researcher receives a response to any of the messages, they will respond with a short note in the following form: 1) 1 sentence thanking the sender for the message (standardized), 2) 1-2 sentences concisely responding to any specific question/comment, taking care not to provide any information that is not available in any of the documents provided to all treated individuals or not common knowledge, 3) a one paragraph restatement of the study (standardized).

q23.value: The study was deemed exempt from IRB review by the Yale Human Subjects Committee (IRB protocol ID 2000020388).

q5.value: This material is based upon work supported, in part, by the National Science Foundation (SES-1423944, PI: Daniel Pemstein), Riksbankens Jubileumsfond (M13-0559:1, PI: Staffan I. Lindberg), , & the Knut & Alice Wallenberg Foundation (PI: Staffan I. Lindberg). Paige Ottmar provided research assistance, Steven Wilson integrated the experiments with V-Dem’s coding interface, and Josefine Pernes & Natalia Stepanova provided administrative support.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan describes three studies bundled with V-Dem’s annual data collection update in 2018. The first study examines how expert coders respond to different participation inducements, and asks how pay and recruitment language affect participation, attrition, and coder attentiveness. The second study asks if we can leverage experts’ shared notions about democratic institutions to aggregate low-level information about democratic institutions into higher-level measures of democracy. The third study asks if we can use experts’ pairwise rankings of cases with respect to specific V-Dem indicators to recover information consistent with that produced by the standard process (Likert scale response) for eliciting ratings from V-Dem experts.

Lindberg), , & the Knut & Alice Wallenberg Foundation (PI: Staffan I. Lindberg). Paige Ottmar provided research assistance, Steven Wilson integrated the experiments with V-Dem’s coding interface, and Josefine Pernes & Natalia Stepanova provided administrative support.

The third study asks if we can use experts’ pairwise rankings of cases with respect to specific V-Dem indicators to recover information consistent with that produced by the standard process (Likert scale response) for eliciting ratings from V-Dem experts.

attributes.title: Understanding the Downstream Effects of Aid on Political Perceptions and Behavior

q1.value: Understanding the Downstream Effects of Aid on Political Perceptions and Behavior

q5.value: This research was supported by AidData at the College of William and Mary and the USAID Global Development Lab through cooperative agreement AID-OAA-A-12-00096., Additional support is provided by the London School of Economics and Political Science Research Incentives Fund and The Suntory and Toyota International Centres for Economics and Related Disciplines.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This experiment is an evaluation of the political downstream effects of the allocation of foreign development project aid. In 2015, the PIs executed a field experiment examining the allocation of NGO-provisioned school aid by local councillors in Malawi (Jablonski and Zimmerman 2015). This earlier project resulted in the constrained and randomized allocation of school aid and provides us with a unique opportunity to evaluate the causal effects of aid on perceptions of government, voting, and beliefs about government and NGO performance.

q17.value: To evaluate these effects, we conducted baseline and endline surveys before and after the delivery of school aid. These were conducted among voters in three separate groups: (1) communities that were selected by the elected councillors to receive goods and received them after selection in the lottery, (2) communities that were selected by the elected councillors to receive goods but did not receive them because they were not selected in the lottery; (3) communities that were not selected by the elected councillors to receive goods. Within each community, we measured perceptions of the councillor, perceptions of the allocation process, and anticipated voting behavior. By collecting baseline and endline voter survey data, and by including these three groups in the process, we expect to be able to isolate aggregate differences in public opinion that are due to the influx of development goods in the community from such differences that are due to simply being favored by the political process or national shifts in public opinion over time. Also, unlike other studies, we can evaluate voter perceptions in precisely those places where politicians have chosen to allocate development goods. This provides us with a more realistic and arguably a “most likely” case for seeing an effect of aid on public opinion and political behavior. The results of this study will allow us to validate our priors that voters value the allocation of donor development goods and often attribute such goods to the influence of elected leaders.

q24.value: National Commission for Science and Technology, Malawi

attributes.title: Public Fears of Terrorism, Partisan Rhetoric, and the Foundations of American Interventionism

q1.value: Public Fears of Terrorism, Partisan Rhetoric, and the Foundations of American Interventionism

q2.value: Daniel Silverman | Daniel Kent | Christopher Gelpi

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study examines how perceptions of the danger posed by terrorist attacks can be lowered to a more accurate level among the American population. An American’s yearly chance of being killed by a terrorist attack sits at about 1 in 3.5 million. Yet over 40% of the public have been consistently found to believe they or a family member are likely or very likely to be the victim of a terror attack. Can these heightened estimates of the risks posed by terrorism be brought closer to reality? With trillions of dollars spent on the War on Terror since 9/11, this question is not just theoretically important – both for research on terrorism and U.S. foreign policy as well as on the correction of false beliefs – but also practically important as well.

q16.value: We explore whether corrective information about the actual risks of terrorism facing Americans will reduce misperceptions. Our core hypothesis is that the efficacy of this “corrective message” will depend on accompanying endorsements of this new information by political elites. We test the impact of the endorser’s (1) partisan identity, (2) deviation from expected positions, and (3) issue-specific expertise on the efficacy of the corrective information.

q17.value: With support from Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences (TESS) and their partner NORC at the University of Chicago, we will field a nationally representative survey experiment that includes a brief vignette with corrective information about the actual risks of terrorism vs. other threats facing Americans such as cancer, car accidents, and homicide. Our study employs a fully randomized design with four treatment groups and one control group. The control group only receives a vignette that captures the general perception of terrorism as threatening. The treatment groups each read the control vignette and then are provided a corrective vignette with information on the risk posed by terrorism relative to other everyday threats. The first treatment group’s vignette only includes these risk statistics. The remaining three treatment group vignettes also include an endorsement of the risk statistics by one of three fictitious elite actors: a Democratic congressman, a Republican congressman, or a military general. This design allows us not only to (1) measure who is the most effective source for corrective information among realistic American elite messengers about the terror threat, but also to (2) test the impact of the different mechanisms for why such cues might effectively reinforce these corrections (see the Pre-Analysis Plan for our method of teasing out each mechanism). We will also field the same revised design simultaneously on MTurk in order to provide additional evidence and investigate the ability of MTurk to recover the results of experiments like ours as compared to high-quality, representative platforms.

q25.value: April 2, 2019 for CMU; April 22, 2019 for OSU

q27.value: Researchers, NORC at the University of Chicago (for nationally representative probability sample, MTurk sample done by research team themselves)

registration_responses.q1: Public Fears of Terrorism, Partisan Rhetoric, and the Foundations of American Interventionism
registration_responses.q2: Daniel Silverman | Daniel Kent | Christopher Gelpi
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: This study examines how perceptions of the danger posed by terrorist attacks can be lowered to a more accurate level among the American population. An American’s yearly chance of being killed by a terrorist attack sits at about 1 in 3.5 million. Yet over 40% of the public have been consistently found to believe they or a family member are likely or very likely to be the victim of a terror attack. Can these heightened estimates of the risks posed by terrorism be brought closer to reality? With trillions of dollars spent on the War on Terror since 9/11, this question is not just theoretically important – both for research on terrorism and U.S. foreign policy as well as on the correction of false beliefs – but also practically important as well.
registration_responses.q16: We explore whether corrective information about the actual risks of terrorism facing Americans will reduce misperceptions. Our core hypothesis is that the efficacy of this “corrective message” will depend on accompanying endorsements of this new information by political elites. We test the impact of the endorser’s (1) partisan identity, (2) deviation from expected positions, and (3) issue-specific expertise on the efficacy of the corrective information.
registration_responses.q17: With support from Time-Sharing Experiments for the Social Sciences (TESS) and their partner NORC at the University of Chicago, we will field a nationally representative survey experiment that includes a brief vignette with corrective information about the actual risks of terrorism vs. other threats facing Americans such as cancer, car accidents, and homicide. Our study employs a fully randomized design with four treatment groups and one control group. The control group only receives a vignette that captures the general perception of terrorism as threatening. The treatment groups each read the control vignette and then are provided a corrective vignette with information on the risk posed by terrorism relative to other everyday threats. The first treatment group’s vignette only includes these risk statistics. The remaining three treatment group vignettes also include an endorsement of the risk statistics by one of three fictitious elite actors: a Democratic congressman, a Republican congressman, or a military general. This design allows us not only to (1) measure who is the most effective source for corrective information among realistic American elite messengers about the terror threat, but also to (2) test the impact of the different mechanisms for why such cues might effectively reinforce these corrections (see the Pre-Analysis Plan for our method of teasing out each mechanism). We will also field the same revised design simultaneously on MTurk in order to provide additional evidence and investigate the ability of MTurk to recover the results of experiments like ours as compared to high-quality, representative platforms.
registration_responses.q25: April 2, 2019 for CMU; April 22, 2019 for OSU
registration_responses.q27: Researchers, NORC at the University of Chicago (for nationally representative probability sample, MTurk sample done by research team themselves)

attributes.title: Can partisan canvassing increase voter turnout at a low saliency election? A UK-based partisan field experiment: Pre-Analysis Plan

q1.value: Can partisan canvassing increase voter turnout at a low saliency election? A UK-based partisan field experiment: Pre-Analysis Plan

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study seeks to examine - with a field experiment – whether voter engagement can be increased through exposure to personal partisan campaign treatment. Specifically, I seek to test whether exposure to personal door-to-door campaign treatment increases voter turnout in comparison to impersonal contact and no contact. In addition, I seek to assess whether this effect differs according to a pre-existing covariate measuring party support. As far as we are aware, this experiment represents one of the few partisan field experiments conducted in the UK (notable exceptions being Foos and John, 2016, for example). The experiment broadly replicates Foos and John’s study, utilising similar partisan treatments, and interacting the effects with subjects’ (pre-existing) party support. This experiment aims to build on Foos and John’s work by also interacting effect with a covariate capturing whether a subject is registered as a postal voter or a non-postal voter. This second interaction seeks to test whether mobilisation effects differ between higher propensity and lower propensity voters at the same election.

q16.value: The hypotheses/treatment I seek to test is determined by the results of a survey of Welsh Election Study participants, who were asked to ‘rank in order of preference’ the top 3 ways they prefer parties to contact them at election time. The results of this study identify leaflets as being a highly preferred campaign method, while doorstep visits were relatively unpopular. As such, and to test the effectiveness of a popular versus an unpopular campaign method in accordance with the study’s guiding theory, the treatments in this experiment will be a partisan leaflet and a partisan canvass visit. Heterogeneous Treatments: Partisan Leaflet Only – A partisan leaflet from the Liberal Democrats advocating local partisan-toned issues. Partisan Leaflet followed by a Canvass Visit – A visit by a Liberal Democrat volunteer (in this study, the researcher himself). The visit will include information about the ‘upcoming election’, location of the nearest polling station, and an encouragement to vote Liberal Democrat. All attempted and successful canvass visits will be preceded by the delivery of a partisan leaflet.

q17.value: I anticipate that exposure to a personal canvass visit will increase voter turnout compared to both the leaflet and the control group (H1). Heterogeneous effects: the second hypothesis stipulates that the effect of the canvass visit will be conditioned by the covariate of pre-existing party support. I anticipate that the effect of the canvass visit will be higher among supporters of that party (H2). Using difference-in-means, I will test my hypotheses using a one-sided test based on the hypothesis that canvass treatment will have a unidirectional positive impact. The following analysis will be conducted: - ITT of Canvass v. Leaflet v. Control (effect of canvass visit) My expectation of ITT effect size is based on previous GOTV studies involving canvass treatments. Effect sizes in this field indicate that the impact of partisan GOTV treatments is in the region of 2-3 percentage-points. I anticipate that the ITT will be higher among party supporters (i.e. interacting the ITT with pre-identified party support).

registration_responses.q1: Can partisan canvassing increase voter turnout at a low saliency election? A UK-based partisan field experiment: Pre-Analysis Plan

q5.value: This study is funded by the Tata Centre for Development at the University of Chicago.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The Rohingya were involuntarily forced from their homes in Myanmar and some migrated to India. Since the migration was involuntary, we might deduce that it reduced the welfare of these refugees. However, there may be distributive effects within the Rohingya community. Specifically, Rohingya women may have, in some respects, been made better off by the migration. Weakening of community strictures may have eased limitations on women’s freedom. Moreover, the availability of outside options – e.g., the ability to leave the community and survive – may have improved their bargaining power. In this project we test whether female Rohingya refugees in India are better off in some respected than they were back in Myanmar.

q16.value: We test 1 overarching hypothesis: Are female Rohingya refuges in India better off in some respects than they were in Myanmar. In testing this hypothesis, we examine 5 specific outcomes: • Can Rohingya women work outside the home? • Can Rohingya women travel more freely in the city? • Can Rohingya daughters go to school? • Can Rohingya women participate in community decisionmaking? • Are Rohingya women subject to domestic violence?

q17.value: We test this hypothesis using a quasi-difference-in-difference design. Our initial difference compares Rohingyan’s women’s self-reported outcomes in India with their recollection of outcomes when they last lived in Myanmar. We employ a second difference, how recollections of outcomes in Myanmar changes over successive waves of immigration, to net out trends in women’s status in Myanmar.

q19.value: Initially, the sample size is 200 households. We will dynamically adjust this by looking at outcome variable means and SDs and determine if we have power (80% power, 5% confidence) to detect an MDE equal to a fixed fraction (eg 0.5) of an outcome’s SD.

q27.value: No intervention. This is an observational study.

registration_responses.q5: This study is funded by the Tata Centre for Development at the University of Chicago.
